user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_get_timeout:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_get_timeout (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
                 MHD_UNSIGNED_LONG_LONG *timeout)
{
  uint64_t t64;
  if (MHD_NO == MHD_get_timeout64 (daemon, &t64))
    return MHD_NO;

#if SIZEOF_UINT64_T > SIZEOF_UNSIGNED_LONG_LONG
  if (ULLONG_MAX <= t64)
    *timeout = ULLONG_MAX;
  else
#endif /* SIZEOF_UINT64_T > SIZEOF_UNSIGNED_LONG_LONG */
  *timeout = (MHD_UNSIGNED_LONG_LONG) t64;
  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#if SIZEOF_UINT64_T > SIZEOF_UNSIGNED_LONG_LONG
  if (ULLONG_MAX <= t64)
    *timeout = ULLONG_MAX;
  else
#endif /* SIZEOF_UINT64_T > SIZEOF_UNSIGNED_LONG_LONG */
  *timeout = (MHD_UNSIGNED_LONG_LONG) t64;
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. After preprocessing there are two possible outcomes: if SIZEOF_UINT64_T > SIZEOF_UNSIGNED_LONG_LONG is true, the code becomes an if (...) … else *timeout = (MHD_UNSIGNED_LONG_LONG) t64; (both branches reachable at run time); if the condition is false, only the single assignment *timeout = (MHD_UNSIGNED_LONG_LONG) t64; remains. In neither case is any statement rendered unreachable, so MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is not violated.
